claim: Cell- and egg-based flu vaccines have the potential to develop mutations during production, which may reduce their effectiveness.
explanation: Composite figure showing ELISA antibody titers (Log2 scale) against egg‐derived HA and cell‐derived HA antigens for four licensed influenza vaccines (two egg‐based: Fluzone IIV4, Fluarix IIV4; one cell‐culture based: ccIIV4; one recombinant: RIV4) at Day 0, 1 month, and 6 months post‐vaccination (Panel A), the geometric mean ratio of egg HA to cell HA ELISA titers at 1 month (Panel B), stalk‐specific ELISA titers against H3 and H1 stalk domains over time (Panel C), and fold‐rise of stalk ELISA titers at 1 month versus Day 0 (Panel D). The figure presents immunogenicity data comparing antibody responses to egg-derived versus cell-derived hemagglutinin, but does not show any data on mutations arising during vaccine production or directly link such mutations to reduced effectiveness. Therefore, it does not support the claim. Note: Interpretation limited by absence of sequence or functional data on production‐induced mutations; only antibody binding titers are shown.
